A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like:
A derivative and largely uninteresting movie\, with some genuinely cringe-worthy moments. This film takes all the bad parts of both The Force Awakens and the Prequels and exacerbates them; imagery and entire scenes are lifted from the OT without context\, characters' actions don't make any sense\, the sense of scale and wonder of the Star Wars galaxy is nowhere to be seen nor are the universe's internal rules followed. There's an entire subplot that comes off like a sidequest from a video game and doesn't contribute anything to the greater story\, complete with some Prequel-esque CGI creature antics and hamfisted Saturday morning cartoon-worthy messages.

There are some interesting ideas with the Force thrown around\, but none of it leads anywhere. Mark Hamill does great job as Luke\, despite clearly disagreeing with the assassination his character is subjected to. Adam Driver is entertaining as Kylo Ren; Rey is still bland as a plank; Snoke ends up amounting to nothing but the low-rent Palpatine everyone always assumed him to be. There's also some genuinely irritating thematic dissonance with the messages the movie is trying to get across -- lambasting core themes of the series such as heroism and sacrifice -- while also glorifying such themes when it comes to the writers' pet characters (such as the completely out-of-place Admiral Purple Hair).

On top of that there's some annoyingly out of place MCU-style self-aware "wink wink nudge nudge" humor that effectively prevents us from taking the film's main villains seriously\, which was already a problem with the last film.

If this is the best they could do\, then there was no point to continuing the Star Wars story after Return of the Jedi.
